Share Feyisa Lilesa: Rio 2016 protest marathon runner reuited with family - Yahoo7 Feyisa Lilesa couldn't return to his native Ethiopia after a controversial political statement in Rio six months ago. Only now has he reunited with his family. Close Feyisa Lilesa's protest in Rio marathon UP NEXT VIDEO Feyisa Lilesa's protest in Rio marathon. Source: Channel 7 Feyisa Lilesa's protest in Rio marathon 
Lilesa caused outrage in his home country when he raised his arms in an X formation as he finished second in the marathon at Rio 2016, protesting against the Ethiopian government's persecution of his Oromo people. 
More than 400 Oromo were reportedly killed between November 2015 and last year's Olympics. 
The protest made Lilesa a hero to his people, but a target in the ethnic warfare. The controversial protest. Image: Getty 
"The Ethiopian government is killing my people, so I stand with all protests anywhere, as Oromo is my tribe," Lilesa said during the Olympics. 
"My relatives are in prison, and if they talk about democratic rights they are killed." 
"If I go back to Ethiopia, maybe they will kill me. If not kill me, they will put me in prison. I have not decided yet, but maybe I will move to another country," he said. Lilesa hugs his wife and kids. Image: Twitter 
Lilesa sought political asylum in the US and moved to Flagstaff, Arizona under a special O-1 visa because of his status as a star athlete. 
However when he attempted to get his family into the US he was roadblocked by President Trump's travel ban. 
But after six months of fear, uncertainty and disappointment, the 27-year-old finally reunited with wife Iftu Mulisa, five-year old daughter Soko Feyisa Lilesa and three-year old son Sora Feyisa Lilesa on Wednesday - Valentine's Day no less. 
"Despite my physical safety here in the US and now a family reunion, the Ethiopian government's ongoing abuse of the Oromo people gives me no rest," he said. Beautiful. Images: Twitter 
"I want to make sure that we don't forget the plight of millions of Oromo and other Ethiopians who are still being killed, beaten, imprisoned, dispossessed and kept in poverty. 
"I will continue to speak out against injustice and its perpetrators. My biggest wish is to see the freedom of my people â€” all people, in every country."
